I just created the channel <#C05Q6S60NFQ|> for folks that are collaborating (or want to collaborate) on the spanish translation of core contents, please join directly if you want in!
If any other languages need a specific channel to work and discuss, hit me up and I can create it for you.

text: We are discussing the landing page now: <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki/Conventions-for-translations>

elements.text: We are discussing the landing page now:

text: <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/issues/16>

attachments.text:
As per <https://github.com/hturner|@hturner> at <https://r-contributors.slack.com/archives/C0210D7EN1X/p1684139203621999|https://r-contributors.slack.com/archives/C0210D7EN1X/p1684139203621999>:

> From the discussion at the last RCWG meeting I think our best option is the dedicated reviewers workflow: <https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#dedicated-reviewers|https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#dedicated-reviewers>. Then we can do the following:
> 
> • Make all existing translators reviewers
> • Encourage reviewers to review translations by other people with custom search: state:>=translated AND NOT changed_by:OwnUserName
> • If no one else reviews their translations after at least 1 month, reviewers can self-review - looking a second time should help avoid mistakes
> • New users are initially added as translators only and can be asked to be made reviewers
> 
> In this scenario, translations would only be added to the R sources when they have been approved, so it does require more work, but should ensure better quality translations. Alternatively, we could use the following workflow, which is closer to what we do currently:
> 
> • Encourage translators to leave "need editing" checked if they want their translation to be reviewed
> • Encourage translators to review translations by other people with custom search: state:needs-editing AND NOT changed_by:OwnUserName
> • If no one else reviews their translations after at least 1 month, reviewers can self-review - looking a second time should help avoid mistakes
> 
> With this second workflow, experienced translators can be trusted to directly translate with no review. However, we rely on translators to self-moderate and we're more vulnerable to a bad actor submitting nonsense/spam translations. What do people think?
attachments.title: #16 Translation review process

text: <https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#dedicated-reviewers>

attachments.text: Using Weblate is a process that brings your users closer to you, by bringing you closer to your translators. It is up to you to decide how many of its features you want to make use of. The followin...
attachments.title: Translation workflows

text:
There's been a lot of movement on the translations wiki today, with updates to the home, the guidelines for translation and the specific language guidelines <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki>
We are thinking of using the first half of the working session tomorrow 10.30 to wrap up the overall guidelines for all the translations, that doesn't have much content as of right now. I think that would be a great use of our time in the sprint, we can finish working on the language-specific guidelines after, but the general guidelines would benefit from a discussion

text: unfortunately the related Slack convo is not available any more (older than 90 days), but MS Translate provided the most generous free tier: <https://azure.microsoft.com/en-gb/pricing/details/cognitive-services/translator/|2M chars/month>. I've checked now again quickly, and Google also has free tier, but only <https://cloud.google.com/translate/pricing|500k chars/month>, so there's a risk that we run out of it and someone will have to pay for the related service :zipper_mouth_face: I feel OK having my card registered with MS as I doubt we will hit the 2M char limit, but would be worried with adding more service providers with lower free tier

text:
Hi folks. I've added a new translation project covering the recommended-priority packages (`Matrix`, `MASS`, `nnet`, `survival`, `lattice`, etc). PTAL!

<https://translate.rx.studio/projects/the-r-project-recommended-packages/>

We are curious about setting up new teams for these projects. Would the existing team leaders prefer to also be leaders on the new packages? Or should we have independent teams?

text:
Hi everyone, thanks to development team for your work. Anybody konw why the position arguments of placeholders lost in source code? for example in `base` c file message: `%s not available for %s in packages "%s"` should be `%1$s not available for %2$s in packages "%3$s"` , This is very important for translation, and the translator needs to adjust the word order according to the positional parameters. in Chinese for example these will be translated as `包 "%3$s" 中的 %1$s 对于 %1$s 不可用` i think it's also available for other language translation.
Is it necessary to add such a position parameter? with thanks!

elements.text: Hi everyone, thanks to development team for your work. Anybody konw why the position arguments of placeholders lost in source code? for example in
base
c file message:
%s not available for %s in packages "%s"
should be
%1$s not available for %2$s in packages "%3$s"
, This is very important for translation, and the translator needs to adjust the word order according to the positional parameters. in Chinese for example these will be translated as
包 "%3$s" 中的 %1$s 对于 %1$s 不可用

i think it's also available for other language translation.
Is it necessary to add such a position parameter? with thanks!

text: Hi Shun, thanks for your concern! you can add those to the Chinese translation even if they're absent in the original English message.

elements.text: Hi Shun, thanks for your concern! you can add those to the Chinese translation even if they're absent in the original English message.
